results.title: The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat
results.brief_description: The Lumière brothers’ famous actuality film of people waiting for a train to arrive at La Ciotat.

constellations_other.name: The Lumière brothers
constellations_other.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

results.title_for_label: The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat
results.description: A group of people are standing along the platform of a railway station in La Ciotat, waiting for a train. One is seen coming, at some distance, and eventually stops at the platform. Doors of the railway-cars open and attendants help passengers off and on. Popular legend has it that, when this film was shown, the first-night audience fled the café in terror, fearing being run over by the “approaching” train. This legend has since been identified as promotional embellishment, though there is evidence to suggest that people were astounded at the capabilities of the Lumières’ cinématographe.

results.title: The Arrested moment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present”.
This program explores how painters have achieved movement in a still image and have told stories in a single frame. Before photography, it did not occur to artists to isolate single moments. Medieval art saw the eternal moment, but with Renaissance art action became central. The program looks at how Michelangelo, Raphael, Titian, Leonardo and Caravaggio treated movement and then moves to the post-photography era and the works of Muybridge, Hockney, Duchamp and Pollock.

results.brief_description: When Madame Adelaide Bonfamille leaves her fortune to Duchess and her children—Bonfamille’s beloved family of cats—the butler plots to steal the money and kidnaps the legatees, leaving them out on a country road. results.title: The Aristocats
results.creator_credit: Wolfgang Reitherman, Winston Hibler and Walt Disney Animation Studios
results.brief_description: Featuring the voices of Phil Harris and Eva Gabor, this Disney animated favourite is filled with lovable characters and “swingin’ music”. When an eccentric millionairess wills her entire estate to her pet cats, her greedy butler abandons them in the French countryside so he can inherit the money himself. Duchess and her three adorable kittens embark on an adventure-filled journey back to Paris, with a street-wise Casanova alley-cat named O’Malley.

results.title: The Archive project
results.brief_description:
Melbourne documentary filmmaker John Hughes will join ACMI as artist in residence in order to produce an exhibition, DVD, book and film program dedicated to the work of the Melbourne Realist Film Unit. The exhibition is scheduled for September 2004. REVISED: The Archive Project will be exhibited as part of 2006 Contemporary Commonwealth.

People involved with the Realist Film Unit made twelve films between 1946 and 1951. Some of these are lost. Those saved are held by Screen Sound Australia. These projects have received some attention in unpublished theses. However, the important work of the Melbourne realists remains largely ‘hidden history’ to a wider public.

John Hughes and/or ACMI may draw further finance for the production of the work, through ACMI, or independently through JH from grants. JH in collaboration with ACMI will seek partnerships in the project. JH will work from ACMI at Federation Square and participate in ACMI’s activities. He will also act as a mentor for ACMI staff.

results.title: The Arab refugees
results.creator_credit: Martin Bunnel, Ben Park and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: 1.3 million Arab refugees now live in camps on both sides of the Jordan, in Gaza, and in neighbouring Arab lands. Since 1949 the U.N. relief agency has been working to provide emergency food and shelter, education and long term job training. But the presence of these proud, angry and uprooted people must continue to be an obstacle to peace - they are humans being denied fundamental rights.

results.title: The Apprentice
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Alan Harkness and Fontana Films
results.brief_description: Answers the questions of potential apprentices and their parents about how the apprenticeship scheme works in Australian industry by concentrating on Robert, an apprentice fitter and turner with an automotive firm. Robert, his father and his supervisor give their views on the training involved, which is intended to develop a boy’s character as well as to produce a good craftsman.

results.brief_description: Designed to bring home sharply to the line manager the potential problems in failing to conduct appraisal interviews professionally. FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.
